data.body:


data.title: More documentation needed for helping contributors
data.body:
Can we get more documentation telling new contributors how to do the following?
- create a test ( including adding the class to GwtTests under utils)
- do whatever needs to be done for the tests to work in GWT (this is the part I don't know)

data.title: ParticleEffect: Don't dispose external textures
data.body: ParticleEffect disposed textures loaded from the assetmanager. This PR should fix this.

data.title: Added a way to change the Assets loader base URL for some special cases
data.body:
Added a way to change the Assets loader base URL for some special cases overriding the getPreloaderBaseURL() method in the GWTLauncher.
To give the reason, we are working on a 3D view on a website in Ruby/Rails and we cannot put the assets folder at the root, so this change will allow a change on the way to get the assets folder in some advanced integration like this one.
Of course it won't change anything if the method is not overridden.

data.title: handle size error, consistent variable names
Add x86 build
data.body:
It allows to execute application at near native performance on Android emulator
when using x86 system image, KVM enabled and GPU Acceleration.

It helps me a lot when recording screencast for my apps

gdx-bullet x86 build is not included

data.title: [feature request] Entity Management System
data.body:
First off, wanted to say that I'm a big fan of libgdx library and Beginning Android Games. Awesome job building a kick ass game development platform. Although I have about 5 years of professional Java experience, I'm quite new to the game development arena. The book and the library allowed me to easily jump head first into creating my first game.

On to the request:

I saw a blog post from a couple of years ago (http://www.badlogicgames.com/wordpress/?p=1951) where @badlogic mentioned that he was not planning to integrate Artemis into libgdx, but rather roll his own Entity Management System. I was wondering if any progress has been made on that front.

I have recently started to work on porting Artemis to use libgdx for containers and pooling. The repo is here: https://github.com/apotapov/gdx-artemis. It's in very early stages. There's still a ton of work to do.

Would there be any interest in adding this Artemis port as a libgdx extension?

data.title: Right-To-Left Text Rendering Support
data.body:
We need to support rendering bitmap fonts for languages such as Arabic, Hebrew which  the rendering of a text starts from right to left.

For that I can contribute but I need some help from the graceful stuff of this framework.

data.title: [Input] Swype Dictionary not showing
data.body:
Swype keyboard does not function correctly. Whenever i focus on textfield swype dictionary bar is not showing up, it doesn't type any letters ( note numbers are fine ) in field unless I press space or enter.

However if i switch to any app, for example google search, i open up my swype keyboard there then swap to the libgdx app I can get it show just one time, however input is still not reflected in textfield.

Phone: Samsung Galaxy S2

data.title: AssetManager: Added get(AssetDescriptor)
data.body:
Quite often I see me writing things like:

```
assetManager.get(ad.fileName, ad.type).createSprite(name);
```

or

```
assetManager.get(ad.fileName, TextureAtlas.class).createSprite(name);
```

Using the AssetDescriptor directly in the get method can make this a little less verbose.

data.title: Gdx.input.getPlaceholderTextInput and Gdx.input.getTextInput appear behind game window
data.body:
This happens consistently in the Desktop version in Windows XP.

I'm using the 9/13/13 nightlies.

It's pretty much a dealbreaker to expect the player to minimize the game to get at the dialog box.
(My game runs in a 1200 x 800 window, not full screen)

It works fine in 32-bit Linux, but on Windows XP the pop-up dialog appears behind the game window. I tried running the JAR directly, and running the JAR from the command line. (I thought there might be a difference -- there wasn't)

data.title: make lwjgl GL* classes non-final
fix not thrown exception
data.body: throw that throwable :)

data.title: 3dapi: remove Lights, add Environment and others
data.body:
Sorry for breaking stuff, but like we discussed, this is probably the last api change (don't pin me on it) I think needs to be added before going stable for 3d api (besides shader graph of course). The change is not fully complete (need to add light attributes), but most API changes are included and I don't want to bloat the PR.
- Separate DefaultShaderProvider and add GLES10ShaderProvider, there's no need to check if gles 20 is available on every call.
- Add DefaultShader.Config, so the DefaultShader isn't bloated with arguments anymore.
- Separate the Attribute class from the Material class
- Add Attributes class which is basically a set of Attribute instances
- Make Material extends Attributes so it only adds an ID
- Rename Lights to Environment and make it extend Attributes
- Make TextureDescriptor generic (T extends GLTexture), restrict TextureAttribute to Texture
- Add CubemapAttribute
- Various other changes

The idea behind this change is that an Attribute (e.g. ColorAttribute) can be set to either the Material and Environment (if the attribute is present in both, the Material will be used). This simplifies shaders (just a bunch of attributes to match with uniforms) and makes environment much more flexible (e.g. add ColorAttribute.Fog to add fog etc.).

There is a downside to this change, e.g. one could add ColorAttribute.Diffuse to the environment (causing all models without a diffuse color to be using that diffuse color). So there is no distinction between material attributes and environment attributes, which might be hard to understand if you're new to the concept. However, it also allows you to "bake" environment attributes onto a model, which I think is justifying this change.

Note that the shader separately receives both material and environment (and the combined attributes if it extends BaseShader), so a shader can still distinct material and environment attributes.

Another downside might be that the number of attributes is limited to the number of bits in long. But I don't expect that's going to be a problem atm.
